cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Feywild
planes.philosophicalEssence: A land of soft lights and wonder, a place of music and magic. The plane responds to unfettered emotion: flowers turn and tremble in the presence of a heated argument, grass withers under the feet of one who seethes with malice, and birds chirp merrily in the presence of those who are joyous and squawk angrily at those who are dour.
planes.emotionalInfluence: The plane responds to unfettered emotion. Its geography, flora, and fauna physically react to the emotions of creatures present.

physicalProperties.shape: Parallel dimension occupying the same cosmological space as the Material Plane
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Breathable; the plane mirrors the Material Plane but is more marvelous, magical, vibrant, and colorful.

temperature.description: Variable, mirroring Material Plane counterparts but often more vivid. Domains of Delight may have perpetual seasons (e.g., Summer Court is wrapped in perpetual summer warmth, Gloaming Court is a realm of twilight and autumn).

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Variable; the plane's weather and environment shift with the emotional states of powerful inhabitants, particularly archfey rulers of Domains of Delight.

timeFlow.description: While time seems to pass normally in the Feywild, characters might spend a day there and realize, upon leaving the plane, that less or more time has elapsed everywhere else in the multiverse. Whenever a creature or group of creatures leaves the Feywild after spending at least 1 day on that plane, the DM can choose a time change or roll on the Feywild Time Warp table. A Wish spell can be used to remove the effect on up to ten creatures. Some powerful Fey have the ability to grant such wishes and might do so if the beneficiaries agree to subject themselves to a Geas spell and complete a quest after the Wish spell is cast.

hazards.name: Feywild Memory Loss
hazards.description: A creature that leaves the Feywild makes a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. Fey creatures automatically succeed on the saving throw, as do creatures that have the Fey Ancestry trait, such as elves. On a failed save, the creature remembers nothing from its time spent in the Feywild. On a successful save, the creature's memories remain intact but are a little hazy. Any spell that can end a curse can restore the creature's lost memories.

hazards.name: Mutable Geography and Distance
hazards.description: Time and distance in the Feywild are mutable, as is the plane's geography. Roads are uncommon, and the ones that exist change as frequently as the land around themselves. Feywild natives are accustomed to the plane's mutability, but it can be terribly disorienting to visitors.

environmentalEffects.name: Emotional Responsiveness
environmentalEffects.description: The Feywild responds to unfettered emotion: flowers turn and tremble in the presence of a heated argument, grass withers under the feet of one who seethes with malice, and birds chirp merrily in the presence of those who are joyous and squawk angrily at those who are dour.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: The plane's flora and fauna physically react to the emotions of creatures present. This is a narrative and environmental effect with no specific mechanical penalty but can alert inhabitants to visitors' emotional states.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: The plane gives physical expression to powerful emotion and excels at metaphor. Characters may find cherished memories or deep regrets stolen and embodied in physical objects like figurines or lockets. A mischievous sprite might steal a character's laughter, robbing them of the ability to laugh until the sprite is found and the laughter—a bouquet of lovely flowers—reclaimed.

portals.name: Fey Crossings

requirement.description: Most fey crossings open infrequently. A crossing might open only during a full moon, on the dawn of a particular day, or for someone carrying a certain type of item. A fey crossing can be closed permanently if the land on either side is dramatically altered—for example, if a castle is built over the clearing on the Material Plane.
requirement.situationCondition: Varies: full moon, dawn of a particular day, carrying a certain type of item, or other specific conditions.

portals.colorOrAppearance: Places of mystery and beauty on the Material Plane that have a near-perfect mirror in the Feywild. A traveler passes through by entering a clearing, wading into a pool, passing into a circle of mushrooms, or crawling under the trunk of a tree.

planarConnections.name: Border Ethereal Overlap
planarConnections.description: The Ethereal Plane's Border Ethereal overlaps the Feywild. Every location on the Feywild has a corresponding location on the Ethereal Plane. Visibility in the Border Ethereal is usually limited to 60 feet. Passing through an opalescent ethereal curtain in the Deep Ethereal leads to the Border Ethereal connected to the Feywild.

planarConnections.name: Material Plane Parallel
planarConnections.description: The Feywild exists in parallel to the Material Plane as an alternate dimension that occupies the same cosmological space. When moving from the Material Plane to the Feywild, travelers usually find themselves in a location similar to the one they left, but more marvelous and magical. Passage between the Material Plane and the Feywild is sometimes effortless, even accidental.

notableEntities.name: Yarnspinner
notableEntities.title: Archfey of Fablerise
notableEntities.description: A story-spinning spider archfey who loves reading stories to the animals that occupy his domain of Fablerise, a rambling thicket of twisted roots, thorny vines, and sinuous creepers.
notableEntities.rulesLocation: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Feywild - Domains of Delight

notableEntities.name: Queen of Air and Darkness
notableEntities.title: Ruler of the Gloaming Court
notableEntities.description: Rules the Gloaming Court, a realm of twilight, fireflies, cobwebs, and autumn leaves. The Fey of the Gloaming Court shun formalized etiquette and rituals, instead prizing behavior that is intuitive and instinctual.
notableEntities.rulesLocation: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Feywild - Domains of Delight

notableEntities.name: Zybilna
notableEntities.title: Archfey of Prismeer
notableEntities.description: Archfey who rules the large domain of Prismeer encompassing Hither (a vast swamp), Thither (an ancient forest), and Yon (a stormy, mountainous landscape). Resides in the Palace of Heart's Desire. On some worlds regarded as a fairy godmother granting wishes for the lost, forsaken, or betrayed.
notableEntities.rulesLocation: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Feywild - Domains of Delight

notableEntities.name: Queen Titania
notableEntities.title: Ruler of the Summer Court
notableEntities.description: Archfey who rules the Summer Court, the most settled and pastoral domain in the Feywild. Wrapped in the warmth of a perpetual summer day with fluttering butterflies and colorful flowers, the court mimics courtly life with elaborate ceremony and ritualized etiquette.
notableEntities.rulesLocation: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Feywild - Domains of Delight

civilizations.name: Summer Court
civilizations.description: The most settled and pastoral domain in the Feywild. Residents wear elegant clothing and value elaborate ceremony and ritualized etiquette. The Fey are quick to shun those who flout the Summer Court's baroque rules.

civilizations.name: Gloaming Court
civilizations.description: A realm of twilight, fireflies, cobwebs, and autumn leaves accompanied by the music of hooting owls and croaking frogs. The Fey shun formalized etiquette and rituals, instead prizing behavior that is intuitive and instinctual.

specialRules.name: Memory Loss
specialRules.description: A creature that leaves the Feywild makes a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. Fey creatures automatically succeed on the saving throw, as do creatures that have the Fey Ancestry trait, such as elves. On a failed save, the creature remembers nothing from its time spent in the Feywild. On a successful save, the creature's memories remain intact but are a little hazy. Any spell that can end a curse can restore the creature's lost memories.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: DC 10 Wisdom saving throw upon leaving the Feywild. Failure: complete memory loss of time in Feywild. Success: memories intact but hazy. Fey creatures and creatures with Fey Ancestry auto-succeed. Any curse-removing spell restores lost memories.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: When a creature leaves the Feywild

onFailure.description: The creature remembers nothing from its time spent in the Feywild.
onFailure.duration: Permanent until cured by a curse-removing spell

onSuccess.description: The creature's memories remain intact but are a little hazy.

recoveryMethods: Any spell that can end a curse

specialRules.name: Time Warp
specialRules.description: While time seems to pass normally in the Feywild, characters might spend a day there and realize, upon leaving the plane, that less or more time has elapsed everywhere else in the multiverse. Whenever a creature or group of creatures leaves the Feywild after spending at least 1 day on that plane, the DM can choose a time change that works best for the campaign, if any, or roll on the Feywild Time Warp table (d20). A Wish spell can be used to remove the effect on up to ten creatures. Some powerful Fey have the ability to grant such wishes and might do so if the beneficiaries agree to subject themselves to a Geas spell and complete a quest after the Wish spell is cast.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Roll d20 on leaving after 1+ days: 1-2 days become minutes, 3-6 days become hours, 7-13 no change, 14-17 days become weeks, 18-19 days become months, 20 days become years. Wish spell removes the effect on up to 10 creatures. Powerful Fey may grant such wishes in exchange for a Geas-bound quest.

modifiedSpells.modification: Can be used to remove the time warp effect on up to ten creatures.
Powerful Fey may require subjects to accept a Geas spell and complete a quest as payment for granting a Wish to remove the time warp effect.

specialRules.name: Mutable Time, Distance, and Geography
specialRules.description: Time and distance in the Feywild are mutable, as is the plane's geography. Roads are uncommon, and the ones that exist change as frequently as the land around themselves. Feywild natives are accustomed to the plane's mutability, but it can be terribly disorienting to visitors.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Distance and geography are not fixed. Roads change frequently. Navigation is unreliable for non-native visitors. The plane's sentient-responsive morphic nature means terrain can shift based on the emotions and desires of powerful inhabitants.

specialRules.name: Emotionally Responsive Environment
specialRules.description: The plane responds to unfettered emotion: flowers turn and tremble in the presence of a heated argument, grass withers under the feet of one who seethes with malice, and birds chirp merrily in the presence of those who are joyous and squawk angrily at those who are dour.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: The environment physically manifests the emotions of creatures present. This can reveal emotional states to observers and may interact with narrative elements (stolen memories embodied as objects, stolen laughter becoming flowers, etc.).

ruler.description: On some worlds regarded as a fairy godmother granting wishes for the lost, forsaken, or betrayed. Sometimes her wishes bring happiness, other times despair.

domainsOrRegions.name: Summer Court

Wrapped in the warmth of a perpetual summer day, with fluttering butterflies and a riot of colorful flowers, the lands of the Summer Court mimic the trappings of courtly life. The residents wear elegant clothing and value elaborate ceremony and ritualized etiquette, and the Fey are quick to shun those who flout the Summer Court's baroque rules.

adventureSituations.situation: People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.

crossReferences.description: Prismeer domain of Zybilna is detailed in this adventure.

planarTravelMethods.name: Fey Crossings
planarTravelMethods.description: Fey crossings are places of mystery and beauty on the Material Plane that have a near-perfect mirror in the Feywild, creating a portal where the two planes touch. A traveler passes through a fey crossing by entering a clearing, wading into a pool, passing into a circle of mushrooms, or crawling under the trunk of a tree. To the traveler, it seems like simply moving into the Feywild. To an observer, the traveler is there one moment and gone the next.
requirements: A crossing might open only during a full moon, on the dawn of a particular day, or for someone carrying a certain type of item
A fey crossing can be closed permanently if the land on either side is dramatically altered
risks: Memory Loss upon leaving the Feywild (DC 10 Wisdom save)
Time Warp (d20 table) upon leaving after 1+ days

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals to Feywild
planarTravelMethods.description: Portals leading to the Feywild can take the form of doorways, fog-shrouded passages, circles of standing stones, or locations that exist on multiple planes. Most have requirements (command words, key items, time constraints, situational conditions, or randomness) and may have guardians.
requirements: Varies by portal: command word, key item, time, situation, or random
risks: Memory Loss upon leaving the Feywild (DC 10 Wisdom save)
Time Warp (d20 table) upon leaving after 1+ days

planarTravelMethods.name: Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: Spells such as Gate and Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to the Feywild. Etherealness allows adventurers to enter the Border Ethereal which overlaps the Feywild.
requirements: Material components as specified by spell
risks: Memory Loss upon leaving the Feywild (DC 10 Wisdom save)
Time Warp (d20 table) upon leaving after 1+ days

planarTravelMethods.name: Ethereal Curtain (Opalescent)
planarTravelMethods.description: In the Deep Ethereal, an opalescent curtain of vaporous color leads to the Border Ethereal connected to the Feywild.
requirements: Must reach the Deep Ethereal first, typically via Plane Shift, Gate, or a magical portal
risks: Ether cyclones in the Deep Ethereal
Memory Loss upon leaving the Feywild (DC 10 Wisdom save)

planarTravelMethods.name: The Great Journey via Feywild
planarTravelMethods.description: It is possible to travel between worlds of the Material Plane through the Feywild, though such routes are less charted and no less perilous than other methods.
requirements: Knowledge of Feywild routes between Material Plane worlds
risks: Memory Loss upon leaving the Feywild (DC 10 Wisdom save)
